full_title_en: Abbey Pain Scale for Dementia Patients
medium_description_en: Assesses pain in patients with advanced dementia.

seo.meta_description_en: The Abbey Pain Scale assesses pain in patients with dementia and other cognitive impairments.
seo.keywords_en: dementia, pain, dementia pain calc, pain in dementia patients, abbey pain scale, abbey ps, abbey pain

how_to_use.use_case_en: Patients with severe dementia and potentially in pain.
how_to_use.pearls_pitfalls_en: The Abbey Pain Scale is a standardized pain assessment tool developed for use in demented nonverbal patients.
how_to_use.why_use_en: Pain assessment is difficult in the dementia population, a group believed to be under-treated for pain. A standardized tool may help improve management.

next_steps.critical_actions_en: Requires a comprehensive examination to assess for physical injuries, vital signs and sources of potential pain.

about.more_info_en:
Score interpretation:

  • Scores ≤2 indicate no pain.
  • Scores 3-7 indicate mild pain.
  • Scores 8-13 indicate moderate pain.
  • Scores ≥14 indicate severe pain.

Note: all scores can be classified by type of pain: acute, chronic and acute on chronic.

Original/Primary Reference.text: Abbey J, et al. The Abbey pain scale: a 1-minute numerical indicator for people with end-stage dementia. Int J Palliat Nurs. 2004 Jan;10(1):6-13

Validation.text: Liu JY, et al. The psychometric qualities of four observational pain tools (OPTs) for the assessment of pain in elderly people with osteoarthritic pain. J Pain Symptom Manage. 2010 Oct;40(4):582-98.

creator_info.about_en: Jennifer Abbey, RN, PhD is a professor of nursing, specializing in aged care at the School of Nursing of Queensland University of Technology and The Prince Charles Hospital Health Service District. She was formerly the director of the Dementia Collaborative Research and Training Centre for Consumers, Carers and Social Research as well as the Deputy Director of the Eastern Australia Dementia Training and Study Centre.
